chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: Which antiviral drug should I prescribe?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Prescribe aciclovir, famciclovir, or valaciclovir, taking into account factors such as contraindications and cautions, adverse effects, and drug interactions, in addition to dosing frequency and acquisition cost.
    • Aciclovir, famciclovir, and valaciclovir are all licensed for the treatment of shingles in adults [ABPI, 2018a; ABPI, 2018b; ABPI, 2019a].
    • Evidence suggests superior efficacy of oral valaciclovir and famciclovir over oral aciclovir for different outcomes. However, the evidence was not consistently reproduced [McDonald et al, 2012; Cohen, 2013; Werner, 2017b; PHE, 2019b]. Studies comparing the effects on cutaneous and pain end points between famciclovir and valaciclovir found that there are no differences in the efficacy [BMJ, 2018].

subChapters.htmlHeader: What are the recommended dosages for oral aciclovir, famciclovir, and valaciclovir?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• The recommended dosages are as follows:
    • For immunocompetent adults:
      • Aciclovir: 800 mg five times a day for 7 days at 4-hourly intervals, omitting the night time dose. 
      • Famciclovir: 500 mg three times a day for 7 days, or 750 mg 1–2 times a day for 7 days.
      • Valaciclovir: 1000 mg three times a day for 7 days.
    • For immunocompromised adults (if they are not systemically unwell and the rash is localized):
      • Aciclovir: 800 mg five times a day for 7 days. Continue for 2 days after the lesions have crusted. 
      • Famciclovir: 500 mg three times a day for 10 days. Continue for 2 days after the lesions have crusted.
      • Valaciclovir: 1000 mg three times a day for 7 days. Continue for 2 days after the lesions have crusted. 
  • In renal impairment:
    • For aciclovir [Joint Formulary Committee, 2019]:
      • If estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) is 10–25 mL/minute/1.73 m2, reduce the dosage to 800 mg every eight hours.
      • If eGFR is less than 10 mL/minute/1.73 m2, reduce the dosage to 800 mg every twelve hours.
    • For famciclovir [ABPI, 2018b]:
      • If creatinine clearance (CrCl) is 40–59 mL/minute, reduce the dosage to 500 mg every twelve hours.
      • If CrCl is 20–39 mL/minute, reduce the dosage to 500 mg once a day.
      • If CrCl is less than 20 mL/minute, reduce the dosage to 250 mg once a day.
    • For valaciclovir [Joint Formulary Committee, 2019]:
      • If eGFR is 30–50 mL/minute/1.73 m2, reduce the dosage to 1000 mg every twelve hours.
      • If eGFR is 10–30 mL/minute/1.73 m2, reduce the dosage to 1000 mg once a day.
      • If eGFR is less than 10 mL/minute/1.73 m2, reduce the dosage to 500 mg once a day.

[ABPI, 2018a; ABPI, 2018b; ABPI, 2019a; Joint Formulary Committee, 2019]

subChapters.htmlHeader: What are the contraindications and cautions for oral aciclovir, famciclovir, and valaciclovir?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Prescribe aciclovir, famciclovir, or valaciclovir with caution in:
    • People with renal impairment and in the elderly (as elderly people are likely to have reduced renal function and are at risk of neurological reactions) [Joint Formulary Committee, 2019].
      • In a person with renal impairment, reduce the dose of the antiviral drug depending on the level of renal impairment. See the section on Recommended dosage for more information.
      • Consider the need for a dose reduction in elderly people.
      • Advise the person to maintain adequate hydration, especially if they are receiving high doses [Joint Formulary Committee, 2019].
  • In people with hepatic impairment:
    • The manufacturer of famciclovir advises that the efficacy may be decreased in severe impairment (risk of impaired conversion to active metabolite) [ABPI, 2018b].

[ABPI, 2018a; ABPI, 2018b; ABPI, 2019a; Joint Formulary Committee, 2019]

subChapters.htmlHeader: What are the adverse effects of oral aciclovir, famciclovir, and valaciclovir?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Aciclovir
    • Aciclovir is generally well tolerated. However, it may cause gastrointestinal adverse effects, such as nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, and abdominal pain. Headache, dizziness, fever, fatigue, and skin rashes (including photosensitivity and urticaria) have also been commonly reported.
    • Other adverse effects of oral aciclovir include:
      • Rare or very rare — agitation, anaemia, angioedema, ataxia, coma, confusion, drowsiness, dysarthria, dyspnoea, encephalopathy, hallucination, hepatic disorders, leucopenia, psychosis, renal impairment, renal pain, seizure, thrombocytopenia, and tremor. 
      • Frequency not known — alopecia and crystalluria.
  • Famciclovir
    • The most common adverse effects of famciclovir are headache, dizziness, gastrointestinal effects (such as nausea and vomiting, abdominal pain, and diarrhoea), skin disorders (such as rashes and itching), and abnormal liver function tests.
    • Other adverse effects of oral famciclovir include:
      • Uncommon — angioedema, confusional state (predominantly in the elderly), somnolence (predominantly in the elderly), and urticaria.
      • Rare — thrombocytopenia, hallucinations, palpitations, and cholestatic jaundice.
      • Frequency not known — anaphylactic shock, anaphylactic reaction, seizure, serious skin reactions (for example erythema multiforme, Stevens- Johnson Syndrome, and toxic epidermal necrolysis) and  hypersensitivity vasculitis.
  • Valaciclovir
    • The most common adverse effects of valaciclovir are headache, dizziness, gastrointestinal effects (such as nausea, vomiting, and diarrhoea), rashes (including photosensitivity), and itching.
    • Other adverse effects of oral valaciclovir include:
      • Uncommon — abdominal discomfort, agitation, confusion, decreased consciousness, dyspnoea, hallucinations, haematuria (often associated with other renal events), leucopenia (mainly reported in immunocompromised people), renal pain, reversible increases in liver function tests (for example bilirubin, liver enzyme), thrombocytopenia, tremor, and urticaria.
      • Rare or very rare — acute renal failure (especially in elderly people or in people with renal impairment receiving higher than the recommended doses), anaphylaxis, angioedema, ataxia, coma, convulsions, delirium, dysarthria, encephalopathy, increased urea and creatinine levels, renal impairment, and psychotic symptoms. 
    • Neurological disorders, sometimes severe, may be linked to encephalopathy and include confusion, agitation, convulsions, hallucinations, and coma. These events are generally reversible and usually seen in elderly people and people with renal impairment.
    • There have been reports of renal insufficiency, microangiopathic haemolytic anaemia, and thrombocytopenia (sometimes in combination) in severely immunocompromised adults, particularly those with advanced HIV disease, receiving high doses (8000 mg daily) of valaciclovir for prolonged periods in clinical trials. These findings have also been observed in people not treated with valaciclovir who have the same underlying or concurrent conditions.

[ABPI, 2018a; ABPI, 2018b; ABPI, 2019a; Joint Formulary Committee, 2019]

subChapters.htmlHeader: What are the key drug interactions with oral aciclovir, famciclovir, and valaciclovir?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Aciclovir and valaciclovir 
    • Aminophylline and theophylline — aciclovir and valaciclovir may increase the plasma concentration of aminophylline and theophylline [Joint Formulary Committee, 2019]. 
      • The manufacturer of aciclovir advises to monitor and adjust dose [ABPI, 2018a; Joint Formulary Committee, 2019].
      • The manufacturer of valaciclovir makes no recommendations [ABPI, 2019a; Joint Formulary Committee, 2019].
    • See the electronic Medicines Compendium (eMC) or the British National Formulary (BNF) for a complete list of possible drug interactions with aciclovir and valaciclovir.
  • Famciclovir — there are no clinically significant interactions with famciclovir [ABPI, 2018b].
